$$
\mu = \mu_ {0} \mu_ {r} = \mu_ {0} (1 + \chi).
$$

The three quantities $\chi$, $\mu_{\mathrm{r}}$ and $\mu$ are interrelated and only one of them is independent. Given one, the other two may be easily determined.

# Solution

(a) The field  $H$  is dependent of the material of the core, and is  $H = nI = 1000 \times 2.0 = 2 \times 10^{3} \mathrm{~A/m}$ .
(b) The magnetic field  $B$  is given by

$$
\begin{array}{l} B = \mu_ {r} \mu_ {0} \mathrm {H} \\ = 4 0 0 \times 4 \pi \times 1 0 ^ {- 7} (\mathrm {N} / \mathrm {A} ^ {2}) \times 2 \times 1 0 ^ {3} (\mathrm {A} / \mathrm {m}) \\ = 1. 0 \mathrm {T} \\ \end{array}
$$

(c) Magnetisation is given by

$$
\begin{array}{l} M = (B - \mu_ {0} H) / \mu_ {0} \\ = \left(\mu_ {r} \mu_ {0} H - \mu_ {0} H\right) / \mu_ {0} = \left(\mu_ {r} - 1\right) H = 3 9 9 \times H \\ \cong 8 \times 1 0 ^ {5} \mathrm {A / m} \\ \end{array}
$$

(d) The magnetising current  $I_{M}$  is the additional current that needs to be passed through the windings of the solenoid in the absence of the core which would give a  $B$  value as in the presence of the core. Thus  $B = \mu_r n (I + I_M)$ . Using  $I = 2\mathrm{A}$ ,  $B = 1\mathrm{T}$ , we get  $I_{M} = 794\mathrm{A}$ .
summary: The given formula represents the relationship between the magnetic permeability (μ), the vacuum magnetic permeability (μ0), the relative permeability (μr), and the susceptibility (χ) of a material. The summary states that these quantities are interrelated and that either of them can be used to determine the other two.
hypothetical_questions: Does the vacuum magnetic permeability (μ0) affect the magnetic permeability (μ) of a material?
How do the relative permeability (μr) and susceptibility (χ) relate to each other?
